Scheme 1 Schematic illustration of the synthesis of the Fe-N-C/NF catalyst. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 SEM and enlarged SEM images of Fe/NF (A,B); and Fe-N-C/NF (C,D). Fig 1 Fig. 2 TEM (A) and corresponding element mapping images of Ni (B), Fe (C), O (D), C (E), and N (F) of as-synthesized Fe-N-C/NF. Fig 2 Fig. 3 The XPS spectra of C1s (A); O1s (B); Fe2p (C); and N1s (D) of as-synthesized Fe-N-C/NF and Fe/NF. Fig 3 Fig. 4 PAL (A) and DB (B) spectra, annihilation intensity I2 of the second positron lifetime component (C), and correlated plot of two characteristic S and W parameters of DB measurements (D) for all prepared samples. Fig 4 Fig. 5 The three possible models of Fe-N-C active sites on the Ni(111) surface: FeN8C20 (A), FeN8C32 (B), and FeN6C24 (C). They are visualized using ball (top-view) and ball-and-stick (side-view) models, respectively. represent Ni and Fe atoms, respectively. The small brown, light blue, and pink balls represent C, N, and H atoms, respectively. The binding energies between these Fe-N-C and the Ni(111) surface are also presented accordingly. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of Fe-N-C/NF (A) (in 1.0 M KOH with and without 0.10 M glucose at scan rate 5 mV·s-1), the polarization curves of GOR (B), the Tafel slope (C), and the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (Cdl) values (D) of as-prepared catalytic electrodes. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Nyquist plots of as-prepared catalytic electrodes for GOR (A) (inset: a fitted equivalent circuit consisting of Rs, CPE, and Rct). Comparison of glucose electrolysis and water electrolysis with the same anodic Fe-N-C/NF and cathodic NF catalysts (B) (scan rate: 5 mV·s-1, with 0.10 M glucose in 1.0 M KOH solution). The stability of Fe-N-C/NF catalyst (C) at potential of 1.70 V vs. RHE. Fig 7 Fig. 8 The optimized structures of the most reactively determined intermediate state, R-HC(OH)O*, on the most energetically stable FeN8C32 (A). The binding energy of this intermediate state on FeN8C32, on the pristine Ni(111), and on the pristine Fe(111) surfaces (B). The reaction energy barrier of the deprotonation reaction from the rate-determined state, and the energy difference between the transition state (TS) and the initial state (IS), and between the final state (FS) and IS (C). In the inset, we present a zoomed-in visualization of the interfaces between the molecule and the surface of the IS, TS, and FS structures, respectively. Fig 8 Table 1 Positron lifetimes (τ1–3), annihilation intensities (I1–3), and S and W parameters obtained for all prepared samples. Errors in the analyzed results are given in Fig. 4. University, Jinju, 52828, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 M.U.D. and T.H.L. contributed equally to this paper. Electrocatalytic glucose oxidation reaction (GOR) has emerged as a potential strategy for energy-saving hydrogen production. The limited electrocatalytic performance of utilized materials has been considered a bottleneck issue. Herein, we present the preparation of Fe-N-C catalyst-encapsulated nickel foam (Fe-N-C/NF) via a one-pot and facile hydrothermal method, employing collagen to provide a coordination environment. Electron microscopy techniques, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, positron annihilation spectroscopy, and density functional theory calculations unambiguously confirm the Fe-N-C species encapsulated on the NF support. Impressively, the achieved Fe-N-C/NF electrode, possessing a high number of active sites, high kinetics, and enhanced charge transport capability, displays outstanding electrocatalytic glucose oxidation activity. The low potential values of 1.31, 1.50, and 1.70 V vs. RHE are required to reach the current density of 10, 50, and 100 mA·cm-2, respectively, which are found to be significantly lower than those of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) counterpart (e.g., 1.57, 1.75, and 1.91 V vs. RHE), implying the outstanding GOR performance of the Fe-N-C/NF material and its potential in the energy-saving hydrogen production. Moreover, the obtained catalyst exhibits stability and a lower working cell voltage for GOR in comparison to OER counterparts, suggesting an impressive application of the electrode for energy-saving hydrogen production via GOR. Graphical abstract FeNC@NF catalyst promotes efficient glucose electro-oxidation for sustainable fuel and biomass valorization. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Hydrogen evolution reaction Fe-N-C Nickel foam Glucose oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen has been pointed out as a crucial energy carrier for future civilization because of its high energy density, renewability, and zero emissions [1]. Indeed, hydrogen is expected to account for 10 to 20 % of net-energy consumption by 2050 [2]. This scenario has challenged and motivated enormous attempts to fill the huge gap between the desired target and technological capabilities. Tremendous efforts have paved the way to explore an efficient route to produce hydrogen at a viable cost [3–5]. To this end, alkaline water electrolysis (AWE), in which hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) occur, respectively, at the cathode and anode in an alkaline medium, has been bearing as the most promising pathway to produce hydrogen [2,6–14]. Recent advances in electrocatalysts for HER and OER have focused on strategies such as heteroatom doping or alloying, defect/vacancy engineering, heterostructure construction, and morphology control to optimize active sites and charge transfer [15–17]. However, this approach has witnessed two critical obstacles: (i) the large overpotential of the OER process, accounting for approximately 90 % of electricity consumption [18–20], and (ii) the possible formation of an explosive H2 and O2 mixture [21]. These limitations stimulate pursuits for alternative pathways to produce hydrogen efficiently. Electrocatalytic hydrogen production coupled with glucose oxidation has arisen as an alternative solution for energy-saving hydrogen production [22,23]. Such an approach offers three features, which could contribute to lowering the hydrogen cost as follows: (i) the reduction of overall input energy compared to electrocatalytic overall water splitting; (ii) the simultaneous conversion of glucose into value-added chemicals (e.g., gluconic, glucaric, lactic acids); and (iii) alternative reactor design [19,24,25]. However, the electrocatalytic performance of the glucose oxidation reaction (GOR) has still been poor, suffering from the sluggish kinetics of GOR. In other words, the active centers have insufficient strength and resilience to conduct the oxidation processes. For these reasons, harnessing a robust material accounts for a crucial position to boost the GOR activity is highly desired. In this direction, the Fe-N-C catalysts have emerged as a compelling substitute to the precious metal-based catalysts in electrocatalytic applications because of their limited metal utilization, low cost, and high activity [26,27]. Thus, numerous investigations have featured the outstanding electrocatalytic performance of Fe-N-C catalysts towards various oxidation applications (e.g., GOR, OER) [28,29]. Hitherto, the application of Fe-N-C catalysts towards GOR has been rarely reported. On the other hand, the preparation of such materials has faced two challenges: (i) harsh synthetic methods and (ii) limited catalyst-support interfacial contact. Typically, the preparation of the Fe-N-C catalyst involves the creation of a coordinative medium followed by the inert-gas-assisted pyrolysis pathway [26,30,31]. However, the limited interfacial contact of the Fe-N-C catalyst could result in high interfacial resistance, restricting the charge transportation during the application. To address this issue, herein, Fe-N-C was in situ grown on a nickel foam substrate (Fe-N-C/NF) through a one-step process using a facile collagen-assisted hydrothermal method. Interestingly, the participation of collagen, possessing numerous functional groups derived from amino acids (e.g., glycine, proline, and hydroxyproline), provides a rich coordinative medium to drive the formation of Fe-N-C species onto the nickel foam rather than metal oxide nanoparticles. Moreover, the utilized synthesis approach, which is entirely different from the other conventional preparation methods, is also found to generate an intimate contact between the active Fe-N-C sites and the conductive scaffold and lead to promoting charge transport. A range of material characterizations was performed to sufficiently unveil the presence and growth mechanism of the Fe-N-C/NF catalyst. Notably, the positron annihilation spectroscopy unambiguously proved and disclosed the on-site formation of Fe-N-C on the NF support. As a result of such direct growth, the developed Fe-N-C/NF system demonstrated an outstanding electrocatalytic GOR. Consequently, the potentials of 1.31, 1.50, and 1.70 V vs. RHE were required to achieve the current densities of 10, 50, and 100 mA·cm-2, respectively. Furthermore, the fabricated Fe-N-C/NF electrode is found to have a greater number of active sites and exhibits low electrochemical resistance. Impressively, the Fe-N-C/NF || NF cell voltage required the potential of 1.62 V to achieve the current density of 10 mA·cm-2, which is significantly lower than that of OER. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and materials Collagen (90 %, CAS number: 9064–67–9) was purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical. Iron nitrate (Fe(NO3)3 ·9H2O), 99 %, and hydrochloric acid (HCl, 38 %) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Ethanol (C2H5OH, > 99 %) was provided by Duc Giang Chemicals. Potassium hydroxide (KOH, 95 %) was purchased from Merck. Glucose (C6H12O6, > 99 %) was provided by VWR Chemicals. All chemicals were used without further purification. Nickel foam (NF) was supplied by Beijing Beike 2D Materials Co., Ltd., with a purity of > 99 % and a thickness of 0.5 mm. 2.2 Material preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of Fe-N-C/NF The NF (3.5 cm × 3.5 cm) was sequentially cleaned with 1.0 M HCl solution and ethanol using ultrasonication for 20 min, followed by rinsing in deionized water and ethanol. The Fe-N-C/NF catalyst was synthesized via a collagen-assisted hydrothermal method. Specifically, 0.404 g of Fe(NO3)3 and 3.0 g of collagen were dissolved in 20.0 mL of deionized water (R > 10.2 MΩ/cm) and stirred vigorously for 2 h. The resulting mixture was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave containing a piece of the pretreated NF and hydrothermally treated at 160 °C for 12 h. After naturally cooling to room temperature, the obtained sample was carefully collected and thoroughly washed several times with deionized water and ethanol, then dried at 60 °C to obtain the Fe-N-C/NF. The Fe-N-C/NF-S1 and Fe-N-C/NF-S2 samples were prepared using a similar procedure as for the Fe-N-C/NF catalyst, except that 2.0 g and 4.0 g of collagen were used, respectively. 2.2.2 Preparation of Fe/NF and HT-NF The Fe/NF and HT-NF samples were prepared under the same conditions as the Fe-N-C/NF synthesis, except without the addition of collagen and Fe(NO3)3, respectively. In addition, a pretreated NF sample that did not undergo the hydrothermal process was also prepared and denoted as NF. 2.3 Material characterizations The morphology of as-synthesized catalysts was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on Vega 3 (Tescan, Czech Republic). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) was carried out on a JEOL (Japan) field-emission electron microscope operated at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. Elemental mapping analysis was conducted on Bruker Detector 630 M (Germany). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a SmartLab diffractometer (Rigaku, Cu Kα radiation,40 kV and 40 mA). Raman spectra were measured by Horiba with a laser wavelength of 532 nm. The X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) was obtained using a K-alpha X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy system. Positron annihilation spectroscopy (PAS) was employed to investigate the defect structure and formation mechanism of the synthesized samples. PAS was performed using a 22Na radioisotope source (< 20 µCi) in a sandwich geometry. Three main measurements of PAS, including positron annihilation lifetime (PAL), Doppler broadening (DB) of positron-electron annihilation energy, and electron momentum distribution (EMD), were employed. For PAL measurements, a fast-fast coincidence spectroscopy with a high time resolution of ∼200 ps using two plastic scintillation detectors (Ortec) was utilized [32]. For DB experiments, a high-purity germanium (HPGe) semiconductor detector (energy resolution of ∼ 1.2 keV at the 511 keV energy peak) was used [32]. The high-quality DB spectra were recorded in a low-background lead box (10 cm of Pb and 2 mm of Cu) to remove the contribution of background radiation. EMD spectra were constructed using DB spectra through the energy-conservation law. A single-crystal silicon sample was used as a reference [33]. All experiments were performed under vacuum conditions. Measured PAL and DB spectra were analyzed by using the LT 9.0 and SP programs, respectively [34]. 2.4 Theoretical modeling Our DFT calculations are based on density functional theory (DFT) using the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof formalism revised for solids (PBEsol) for the exchange and correlation functional. We employ ultrasoft pseudopotentials for the electron-ion interactions, including scalar relativistic effects. The Kohn-Sham wave functions are expanded in plane-wave basis sets up to a kinetic energy cutoff of 40 Ry (480 Ry for the charge-density cutoff). Brillouin zone integrations have been performed using the Gamma special-point technique, smearing the Fermi surface through the Marzari-Vanderbilt cold-smearing technique, with a smearing parameter of 0.03 Ry (0.41 eV). We model the NF, employing a periodically repeated slab geometry for the Ni(111) surface orientations, using a (4 × 4) surface supercell, with the FeNC active sites assumed to be adsorbed on one side of the slab only. The Ni(111) slabs are 5 layers thick, and the bottom two layers of the slab are kept fixed in their bulk positions. A 15 Å vacuum layer is used, which is found to be sufficient to ensure negligible coupling between periodic replicas of the slab. For the calculation of the reaction pathways and the transition state along the minimum energy path of the GOR elementary reaction steps on the FeNC active site, we adopt the climbing-image nudged-elastic band (CI-NEB) method. Relaxation during NEB minimization is performed for all atoms, except the bottom two layers that were kept fixed, until the forces are <0.01 eV/Å. All calculations are performed using the PWscf code integrated into the Quantum ESPRESSO distribution. 2.5 Electrochemical measurement The electrochemical measurements were carried out using the CORRITEST potentiostat in the three-electrode electrochemical system, where as-synthesized catalyst-coated NF, platinum, and Hg/HgO electrode were used as working, counter, and reference electrodes, respectively. The electrolyte used for glucose oxidation was 1.0 M KOH and 1.0 M KOH solution with 0.10 M glucose for HER and GOR, respectively. Each measurement was performed three times to ensure the accuracy of the result. The potentials versus reversible hydrogen electrode (vs. RHE) were used throughout the study and calculated according to the following equation: (1) ERHE = E (Hg/HgO) + 0.059× pH + E0 (Hg/HgO) Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurement was first employed to activate an as-synthesized catalyst at a scan rate of 50 mV·s-1 within 20 cycles. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was conducted at a scan rate of 5 mV·s-1. The Tafel plot was derived from the polarization curves obtained at a low scan rate (0.1 mV·s-1). The electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of the achieved electrocatalysts was measured through CV at various scan rates from 5 – 100 mV·s-1 in non-Faradaic regions. The Cdl of electrodes was determined from the slope of the linear plot of ∆J/2 (the halves of anodic and cathodic current density) versus various scan rates (5 – 100 mV·s-1) [35,36]. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed at the potential of 1.3 V vs RHE in the frequency range of 0.1 Hz – 100 kHz with an amplitude of 10 mV. The stability test of catalysts was carried out by chronoamperometry for 10 h at a potential of 1.7 V vs. RHE with the electrolyte being refreshed every two hours. Cell voltage test was carried out on a two-electrode system consisting of NF and Fe-N-C/NF electrodes as counter and working electrodes, respectively, at a scan rate of 5 mV·s-1. Furthermore, the practical utilization of the catalyst was conducted in an H-type electrochemical cell, and the amount of produced hydrogen was also measured over a period of 10 h by the water displacement method. 3 Results and discussion The Fe-N-C/NF sample was synthesized in situ on a nickel foam via a collagen-assisted hydrothermal method, as depicted in Scheme 1 (see the Experimental Section in Supporting Information for details). In this synthesis process, a required amount of Fe(NO3)3 was dissolved in a collagen-containing solution before being subjected to hydrothermal treatment at 160 °C for 12 h. In this case, the presence of collagen, which bears numerous functional groups (e.g., -NH2, -OH), could form coordination environments around Fe cations. Consequently, such interactions not only limit the corrosion of the Ni surface but also promote the nucleation of Fe-N-C and regulate the growth of Fe-N-C onto the surface of nickel foam. Such features are found to be entirely in contrast to the sample prepared without collagen, in which FexOy-based nanoparticles could be generated. The in situ grown Fe onto a nickel foam sample (denoted as Fe/NF) was synthesized using a similar procedure, as depicted in Scheme S1. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted to investigate the crystalline properties of the as-synthesized samples. The bare nickel foam (NF) was also evaluated for comparison. The NF sample displays two peaks centered at the 2θ values of 44.5° and 52°, which are characteristic signals of Ni metal (Fig. S1A) [37,38]. The sample Fe/NF shows the existence of both NiFe2O4 and Ni phases [39]. These formations could originate from the chemical reactions between Fe3+ cations and the Ni support. Neither characteristic peaks of Fe metal nor iron oxides were observed in the XRD pattern of Fe-N-C/NF sample beyond the default Ni phase, as shown in Fig. S1B. Such evidence implies two essential findings: (i) the presence of collagen significantly influences the deposition behavior of materials and (ii) the possible formation of a distinct phase of the material. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was applied to analyze the morphological features of the as-synthesized samples. The nickel foam (NF) sample exhibits a porous structure with a smooth surface, as shown in Fig. S2. The hydrothermal-treated nickel foam (HT-NF) was also used for comparison. The formation of uniform nanoplates can be observed, as seen in Fig. S3. The SEM images of samples prepared with and without collagen witness a noticeable distinction in the morphological structure, as shown in Fig. 1 . Notably, uniform decoration of Fe-based particles is observed on the surface of NF (Fig. 1 A-B). In contrast, the Fe-N-C/NF sample exhibits an entirely different feature in the formation of Fe-based materials, as indicated in Fig. 1 C-D. The Fe species is entirely distributed over the Ni foam, implying the essential function of collagen, which drives the uniform formation and growth of material onto the nickel support. Such phenomena, which have been rarely observed elsewhere, could offer a robust platform for efficient electron transportation. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) technique was employed to investigate the interior of the as-synthesized samples. Nanoparticles isolated from the Fe/NF sample reveal the interplanar spacing values of 0.25, 0.26, and 0.27 nm, which indicate the diffraction planes of NiFe2O4 (311), Ni(OH)2 (101), and Ni(OH)2 (100), respectively (Fig. S4A-B) [40–43]. Moreover, the energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental mapping of Fe/NF signifies the existence of three elements (i.e., Ni, Fe, and O) within this material (Fig. S4C-F). These findings are consistent with the XRD results obtained. The Fe-N-C/NF sample exhibits a distinct feature in its TEM image in comparison to that of the Fe/NF, as shown in Fig. 2 . Notably, the Fe-N-C/NF sample consists of the agglomerated thin layers (Fig. 2 A). Furthermore, the HR-TEM image of Fe-N-C/NF in Fig. S5 demonstrates ambiguous lattice fringes, suggesting the extremely low crystallinity of the measured material, which is consistent with the XRD result. The energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) elemental mapping of this sample unveils the existence of C and N atoms, in addition to Fe, O, and Ni, as observed in Fig. 2 B-F. Furthermore, elemental mapping images also prove the homogeneous distributions of Fe and other elements in the entire structure, suggesting the possible bonding interaction between them [44]. Fig. S6 shows the Raman spectra of the as-prepared materials. The Fe-N-C/NF system displays unambiguous vibrations in comparison to the other samples, representing a distinct vibrational environment within the system. The peaks centered at the low-frequency region of 150 – 400 cm-1 could be ascribed to the vibrations of metal-ligand [45]. Particularly, a strong peak arising at 188 cm-1 and 207 cm-1 could be attributed to the deformation mode of the N-Fe-N coordination [45,46]. Peaks emerging at 1334 cm-1 and 1554 cm-1 could be ascribed to D and G bands of sp2 graphitic carbons, respectively [46–49]. Such findings disclose the possible existence of the Fe-N-C catalyst. Notably, none of these peaks could be observed in as-synthesized samples without collagen. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization was carried out to understand the intrinsic nature of the prepared catalysts. Table S1 and Fig. S7 show the survey spectra of the samples prepared with and without collagen. The presence of the respective elements and their concentrations, such as C (55.27 atom %), O (27.54 atom %), N (9.55 atom %), Ni (7.4 atom %), and Fe (0.24 atom %), were determined from the survey spectrum of Fe-N-C/NF sample. Fig. 3 A shows the deconvoluted C1s spectra of the Fe/NF and Fe-N-C/NF samples. The XPS C1s of the Fe/NF sample could be interpreted based on three peaks centering at 284.8, 287.19, and 290.54 eV, which could be assigned to CC, C–O, and CO3 2-, respectively [50–52] The high-resolution C1s of the Fe-N-C/NF sample displays notable distinctions. The deconvoluted peaks located at 284.8, 286.4, and 288.2 eV can be assigned to C–C, C–N, and C = O, respectively [48,50]. The interpreted O1s XPS spectrum of the Fe/NF catalyst signifies three primary peaks centered at 529.4 eV, 531.0 eV, and 532.7 eV, which could be ascribed to metal–O lattice, metal–OH, and absorbed water, respectively, as shown in Fig. 3 B [53–57]. In contrast, the O1s XPS spectrum of the Fe-N-C/NF electrode could be deconvoluted into one peak located at 531.3 eV, which could be attributed to C = O [58,59]. These observations suggest the absence of iron oxide species in the Fe-N-C/NF sample, which turns out to be in good agreement with the mentioned characterizations. Fig. 3 C exhibits the high-resolution Fe2p XPS spectra of the as-prepared samples. The Fe2p XPS spectrum of the Fe/NF electrode can be fitted into four primary peaks. The peak centered at 706.0 eV could be assigned to the metallic iron, whereas the peaks located at 712.12 eV and 725.15 eV could be attributed to Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 of the Fe3+ oxidation state, respectively [60,61]. The peak centered at 718.9 eV could be assigned to the satellite of Fe3+[29,62,63]. The deconvoluted Fe2p spectrum of the Fe-N-C/NF sample shows two peaks located at 707.5 eV and 713.6 eV, which could be ascribed to the Fe(II)–N bond and satellite, respectively [46]. Fig. 3 D exhibits the deconvoluted N1s XPS spectrum of the Fe-N-C/NF sample, which can be fitted into two peaks centered at 398.6 and 399.9 eV, respectively. The former can be attributed to N-Pyridinic, while the latter can be assigned to Fe-coordinated N [27,64–66]. Such observations validate the formation of the Fe-N-C system onto the nickel foam support. In this system, collagen serves as a crucial component in facilitating the coordination and in situ growth process, which has not yet been addressed in earlier studies. The positron annihilation spectroscopy (PAS) was further employed to confirm the formation of Fe-N-C catalysts and to analyze their defective structures. Fig. 4 A and Table 1 present the positron annihilation lifetime (PAL) and Doppler broadening (DB) analyses of the prepared materials. PAL analysis reveals three positron lifetime (LT) components τ1–3, which could be assigned to the (i) combined annihilation of positron in perfect lattice and monovacancies (τ1) [32], (ii) positron annihilation in vacancy clusters (τ2) [32] or interfaces [67] of the composites, and (iii) the pick-off annihilation of ortho-positronium (o-Ps) within nanopores (τ3) of the materials [68]. The bare NF sample exhibits the τ1 value of 0.130 ns, which is higher and lower than those of perfect lattice of Ni (i.e., τNi ∼ 0.110 ns) and monovacancies (i.e., τm ∼ 0.175 ns), respectively [69]. This result suggests a high concentration of Ni-monovacancies (VNi) in the NF sample. The τ2 value (0.276 ns), which is relatively small, corresponds to the vacancy clusters involving two vacancies [70], whereas the τ3 value (0.96 ns) is associated with the nanopores with an average size of ∼ 0.32 nm [71]. These vacancy clusters and nanopores exist on the surface of NF because of their low annihilation intensities (I2 = 27.5 % and I3 = 0.33 %) [67,72]. These achieved results reveal that defects-containing NF (vacancy clusters and nanopores) could offer a proper scaffold for the deposition of active materials [72]. Under hydrothermal treatment (HT-NF sample), the τ1 value significantly reduces to 0.119 ns, while those of τ2 (0.281 ns) and τ3 (1.06 ns) slightly increase. The reduction of τ1 , along with the increase in I2 (33.8 %), indicated the reduction of positron trapping probability in VNi of the HT-NF structure. This can be explained by the presence of some interfaces and empty spaces in Ni(OH)2 plates, which could both provide larger areas to generate new phases and competitively trap positrons from VNi that are deeply located in the core of NF. The Fe/NF sample witnesses the simultaneous increases of τ1 (0.130 ns), τ2 (0.308 ns), and τ3 (1.28 ns), while a slight reduction in I2 (27.9 %) was observed, in comparison to the NF and HT-NF samples. Such outcomes suggest the formation of a new phase (e.g., NiFe2O4) due to the added Fe phases, thus providing additional monovacancies and enlarging vacancy clusters (∼ 3 vacancies) and nanopores (∼ 0.41 nm). The Fe-N-C/NF sample exhibits a unique PAL behavior, which is rarely observed. The samples with varying amounts of collagen, Fe-N-C/NF-S1 and Fe-N-C/NF-S2, were prepared to understand the formation and nature of the active centers. Particularly, PAL analysis of the Fe-N-C/NF-S1 sample shows the values of τ1 (0.116 ns), I1 (64.8 %), and I2 (34.5 %) to be very close to those of the HT-NF sample, which implies the presence of interface-rich composites on the surface of Fe-N-C/NF-S1. Similar results are also found for the Fe-N-C/NF-S2 sample. Impressively, the Fe-N-C/NF sample exhibits a simultaneous increase of τ1 (0.141 ns), τ2 (0.297 ns), and τ3 (1.46 ns) values, whereas the associated I2 value decreases to 26.0 %. From this observation, it is characterized that a distinct layer, which possesses a highly coordinative environment, has been deposited onto the NF surface, causing the reduction in average electron density. The electron density around Fe atoms is enhanced due to the coordination bond of Fe–N, thus strongly stretching the Fe–N bonds and promoting electrical conduction [73]. This results in the highest value of τ1 (0.141 ns) obtained for the Fe-N-C/NF sample. Such evidence unambiguously confirms the existence of the Fe-N-C layer on the NF support. In addition, the simultaneous increase of τ3 and I3 implies the improvement of the nanoporous structure on the Fe-N-C/NF surface, which could improve the mass transport during the chemical process. Therefore, it is proposed that the Fe-N-C/NF system contains two features: (i) vigorous stretching of Fe–N bonds causing enhanced electrical conduction and (ii) enhancement of nanoporous structures. These features could pave the way to an outstanding electrocatalytic oxidation performance of this system [73]. The calculated I2 values using a simple mixture rule [74] show a positive deviation from the measured data (Fig. 4 C), suggesting the formation of strong interactions of hydrogen bonds through which the Fe-N-C active centers interact with the Ni surface. In addition, Doppler broadening (DB) measurements show a linear correlation between S and W parameters (Fig. 4 D) obtained for the three Fe-N-C/NF, Fe-N-C/NF-S1, and Fe-N-C/NF-S2 samples, implying the same defect types within them. The highest value of the S parameter, observed for Fe-N-C/NF, indicates the highest concentration of defects in this system, which is consistent with the observed increment of its positron lifetimes τ1–3. The next attempt is to disclose the role of collagen and the formation of Fe-N-C active sites onto the NF support. For this, the electron momentum distribution (EMD) measurements employing different reference samples and associated data analysis were obtained as shown in Fig. S8 and supporting paragraphs. The obtained results suggest three essential points as: (i) collagen molecules offer a highly coordinative and homogeneous environment, containing N-based functional groups and promote the formation of the Fe-N-C centers; (ii) Fe and N can be directly bonded to the NF platform, while C could only participate in the composite matrix and support the formation of Fe-N-C/NF (this result is consistent with the XPS analysis); and (iii) the vacancy cluster-containing NF substrate can bond to functional groups-derived collagen through hydrogen bonds before creating chemical interaction toward Fe cations. The interaction manner mentioned in the third point could promote the encapsulation of Fe-N-C on the entire surface of NF during the synthesis. By employing atomistic simulations based on density functional theory (DFT) [75,76], we examined in detail the possible structures of the Fe-N-C active site formed on the NF. The XPS and PAS- inspired characterizations indicate the structure of the Fe-N-C active site involves N-pyridinic and Fe-coordinated N rings, we proposed three possible Fe-N-C structures, namely, FeN8C20, FeN8C32, and FeN6C24, as shown in Fig. 5 . In particular, the previous works [77,78] suggested that FeN8C32 and FeN6C24 were formed on the graphene surfaces upon mixing FePc powder with carbon black, while FeN8C20 is predicted to resemble the FePc structure, and it has never been reported elsewhere. Our results show that FeN8C20 and FeN8C32 are energetically favorable structures, strongly binding to the Ni(111) surface with binding energies of −1.74 and −1.84 eV, respectively. In comparison to the case of FeN6C24 formed on graphene, these binding energies are slightly smaller, which is only −0.3 eV, yet it remains to grow on the Ni(111) subsurface instead of being buried into it, which is essential for catalysis stability. Fig. 5 indicates that the energetic favorability of the FeN8C20 and FeN8C32 structures is induced by the interaction between the Ni surface atom and its unsaturated C atoms. In contrast, FeN6C24 is not energetically favorable to be bound to the surface, characterized by a positive binding energy value, i.e., 0.84 eV, and a large average distance (>2.8 Å) between FeN6C24 and the Ni surface, resulting in no bond formation. Determining the atomistic geometry of Fe-N-C on Ni(111) is essential for understanding how this active site remains stable during the electrochemical catalysis process, as well as for interpreting the chemical reaction mechanisms. Next, we attempt to explain how Ni surface vacancy defects can stabilize the Fe-N-C active center. First, by removing a single Ni atom either right under the Fe center or one binding to the unsaturated C atom, the binding energy between Ni(111) and FeN8C20, and between Ni(111) and FeN8C32 structures decreases; in contrast, it remains nearly unchanged for the case of the FeN6C24 structure. This finding implies that the Ni surface vacancy does not directly impact the Fe-N-C center; instead, its effect is reflected through stabilizing the collagen functional groups (characterized by OH- and NH2- radicals). To verify this hypothesis, we simulated models of the interaction energy between OH- and NH2- and the Ni(111) surface with and without the existence of a monovacancy on the surface, and computed the binding energies for these cases. The results show that monovacancy increases the binding energy by about 0.5 and 0.6 eV for OH- and NH2-, respectively, compared to those on the pristine surface (Table S2). This energy increase is accompanied by the formation of two bonds compared to that on the pristine surface, as shown in Fig. S9. Also, by analyzing the charge density difference, as shown in Fig. S9, one can find that due to the lack of charge at the monovacancy defect places, there is a rapid charge transfer from the radical to the monovacancy than that on the pristine surface, resulting in a stronger bond between the radicals and surface, verifying the observations from the experiment. Here, we also emphasize that the three above models are intended to capture the local atomic structure around Fe active sites. These sites may exist at low concentrations, as reflected by the low Fe content detected by XPS, but can still dominate the catalytic behavior. As such, the stoichiometry of the DFT models should be interpreted as representative local motifs rather than the direct reflections of the bulk elemental composition measured by XPS. To this end, the employed characterizations and theoretical calculations unveil the function of collagen and the formation mechanism of Fe-N-C catalyst on the NF support. The impressive features of the as-prepared Fe-N-C/NF electrocatalysts offer a robust platform for electrolytic applications. In this case, the GOR evaluations were performed using the typical three-electrode configuration in 1.0 M KOH solution (see the Experimental Section in Supporting Information for details). The electrodes were activated via cyclic voltammetry (CV) scans (i.e., 20 cycles) prior to measurements. To ensure the precision of the material activities, three different synthesises of each sample were conducted and measured. Such a typical measurement can be seen in Fig. S10. Fig. 6 A displays the LSV curves of the Fe-N-C/NF catalyst with and without the presence of 0.10 M glucose. The glucose oxidation reaction requires 1.31 V vs. RHE to achieve 10.0 mA·cm-2, which is significantly lower than that of OER, 1.57 V vs. RHE. This result implies a remarkable energy-saving hydrogen production taking place within the GOR process. Fig. 6 B shows the GOR polarization curves of prepared electrodes such as NF, HT-NF, Fe/NF, and Fe-N-C/NF. The activity of the Fe-N-C/NF sample significantly outperforms the rest of the materials. It should be noted that such electrocatalyst requires the potential of 1.31 V vs. RHE to achieve a current density of 10.0 mA·cm-2, which outperforms the Fe/NF (1.39 V vs. RHE), HT-NF (1.41 V vs. RHE), and NF (1.38 V vs. RHE) electrocatalysts. Impressively, such value is competitive among highly efficient materials, suggesting the outstanding activity of the prepared Fe-N-C/NF electrode (Fig. S11 and Table S3). Tafel slopes are obtained through the applied potential required to achieve the logarithmic increase in the current [79]. This measurement, extracted from the LSV curves, was conducted to examine the electron transfer capability of the obtained materials. A lower Tafel slope can indicate a faster electron transfer rate and improved GOR kinetics [80,81]. As shown in Fig. 6 C, the Tafel slope of the Fe-N-C/NF electrode is found to be 149 mV·dec‑1, which is lower than that of Fe/NF (317 mV·dec‑1), HT-NF (210 mV·dec‑1), and NF (164 mV·dec‑1). Such evidence suggests the superior GOR kinetic reaction taking place over the Fe-N-C/NF catalyst. The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) of the achieved electrocatalysts, employed to evaluate the effective catalytic area, was measured through CV at various scan rates ranging from 5 – 100 mV·s-1, as shown in Fig. S12 and Fig. 6 D. Impressively, the Fe-N-C/NF catalyst achieves the Cdl value of around 7.3 mF·cm-2, which is remarkably higher than that of the Fe/NF (4.7 mF·cm-2), HT-NF (3.2 mF·cm-2), and NF (2.5 mF·cm-2) systems. In other words, the Fe-N-C/NF electrode exposes numerous catalytic centers, providing an appropriate platform in which reaction barrier energies, as confirmed through DFT calculations (shown later), could be lowered to steer the conversion of glucose molecules. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was carried out to investigate interfacial contact and electrical conductivity of the prepared samples. Fig. 7 A exhibits the Nyquist plots, corresponding to an equivalent circuit, electrolyte resistance (Rs), and charge transfer resistance (Rct) measured at 1.3 V vs. RHE. The Rct values of samples are identified in the order as follows: Fe-N-C/NF (2.62 Ω) < Fe/NF (6.13 Ω) < NF (6.86 Ω) < HT-NF (9.37 Ω). It should be noted that the charge-transfer resistance (Rct) represents the kinetics of electron exchange at the electrode surface and the electrical double layer [82,83]. A high Rct value limits the electron transportation from the glucose molecules to the anode. Therefore, such achievements prove that the developed Fe-N-C/NF system paves the way to promote significantly charge migration and the glucose oxidation reaction, which are consistent with the observed characteristics. The next experiment attempts to examine the practical utilization of the Fe-N-C/NF sample for energy-saving hydrogen production using a two-electrode configuration, as shown in Fig. 7 B. The Fe-N-C/NF || NF cell requires a potential of 1.62 and 2.07 V to achieve the current density of 10 and 50 mA·cm-2, which is significantly lower than that of OER. Moreover, the Fe-N-C/NF maintains the H2 production stability over 5 consecutive cycles (c.a., 2 h/cycle) at 1.70 V vs. RHE, as shown in Fig. 7 C. Notably, the catalyst demonstrates consistent output current intensity for a 10-h investigation period corresponding to the H2 evolution rate of 2.04 mmol·cm-2·h-1. Such obtained results imply the robust capability of Fe-N-C/NF catalyst for the simultaneous electrocatalytic hydrogen production and glucose oxidation reaction in alkaline media. The structural stability of Fe-N-C/NF after the durability test was further evaluated by post-characterizations. As presented in Fig. S13, the SEM images of Fe-N-C/NF catalyst indicate a minor alteration in the morphology. EDX spectra and elemental mapping images prove the presence and uniform distribution of Fe, N, and C elements. In addition, the XRD patterns recorded before and after chronoamperometry reveal the absence of a new phase. These results demonstrate the durability of the Fe-N-C/NF catalyst under prolonged electrochemical operation. To elucidate the enhanced performance of Fe-N-C compared to monometallic Ni and Fe in the GOR process, we performed DFT and Nudged Elastic Band (NEB) [84,85] calculations to examine the structure and energetics of the key intermediate state in the GOR process and the reaction energy barriers of the reaction paths from the initial state to the final products. Here, we propose that the electrocatalytic reaction occurs near the thermodynamic limit, which can be the case with a small voltage applied to drive the reaction. In addition, the conversion of glucose into gluconic acid is also considered in the GOR reaction [86]. As the GOR reaction steps have not been examined in detail before, we adopt the commonly accepted mechanism of formaldehyde oxidation reaction as proposed in the literature [87]. The steps of the reactions can be as follows: (i) Initially, R-CHO undergoes hydration and deprotonation in the alkaline solution to generate the R-HC(OH)O anion – where R stands for the C5H11O5 group; (ii) the adsorption of anions onto the catalyst surface, forming R-HC(OH)O* intermediate; (iii) which then undergoes dehydrogenation through CH cleavage, forming R-COOH* and H*; and (iv) to complete the reaction, on the cathode, R-COOH* desorbs from the surface to yield the desired product (R-COOH gluconic acid) in the solution [86]. Within this proposed mechanism, the third step is key in determining the reactivity of the catalysts. In Fig. 8 , we present the side-view of the R-HC(OH)O* intermediate, its binding energy, and the reaction energy barrier of deprotonation in the third reaction step. The results indicate that the relative adsorption energy of R-HC(OH)O* onto the most energetically favorable Fe-N-C (FeN8C32) system is more preferred, with the O anchored at the Fe site, compared to that on Ni(111) and Fe(111). Similarly, the activation energies of both the reactions forming RCOOH* from R-HC(OH)O* and the dehydrogenation from RCOOH are lower on Fe-N-C than on Ni(111) and Fe(111). In Fig. 8 A, the stability of R-HC(OH)O* on Fe-N-C is characterized by the O-Fe bond. Analysis of the projected density of states of the anchored O group of R-HC(OH)O* and of the Fe atom in the Fe-N-C site indicates strong orbital mixings of O-2p with Fe-4d states in the energy range from −2.5 to −5.0 eV, which is the origin of stabilizing the R-HC(OH)O* intermediate state. The reaction barrier energy computed using the NEB calculation is only around 0.9 eV. This energy is equivalent to a reaction rate of 106 s-1 at 300 K. In contrast, on Ni(111), the E* of the same calculation is 1.35 eV, certifying the Fe-N-C reactivity enhancement for the GOR. By connecting to the binding energy of the initial state, we emphasize that the strong binding of R-HC(OH) allows for the stabilization of the transition state of the reaction and is therefore a key mechanism in determining the reactivity of the electrocatalysts. It is worth noting that, while our DFT calculations suggest a plausible pathway for glucose oxidation to glucuronic acid via a rate-determining dehydrogenation step, experimental verification of this product remains an important direction for future work. Techniques such as liquid-phase nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) will be employed in future studies to confirm the presence of glucuronic acid among the oxidation products. 4 Conclusions The presented study attempts to prepare a robust electrocatalyst based on Fe-N-C by employing natural polymer (e.g., collagen) for energy-saving hydrogen production through electrocatalytic glucose oxidation. The conducted characterizations, particularly the positron annihilation spectroscopy, unambiguously revealed the existence and on-site formation of Fe-N-C active sites onto the nickel foam (NF). The achieved Fe-N-C/NF turns out to remarkably promote the electrocatalytic oxidation reaction of glucose. Impressively, the Fe-N-C/NF requires low potentials of 1.31, 1.50, and 1.70 V vs. RHE to reach the current density of 10, 50, and 100 mA·cm-2, respectively, which are significantly lower than those of OER. Notably, the Fe-N-C/NF catalyst also possesses numerous active sites and promotes effective inter and intra-charge transport during the reactions. Furthermore, the prepared Fe-N-C/NF electrode exhibits long-term stability and energy-saving hydrogen production capability, suggesting its potential for efficient hydrogen evolution via GOR. This work also discloses a pathway to prepare high-performance electrocatalysts for hydrogen evolution and other electrocatalytic applications. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic glucose oxidation reaction (GOR) has emerged as a potential strategy for energy-saving hydrogen production. The limited electrocatalytic performance of utilized materials has been considered a bottleneck issue. Herein, we present the preparation of Fe-N-C catalyst-encapsulated nickel foam (Fe-N-C/NF) via a one-pot and facile hydrothermal method, employing collagen to provide a coordination environment. Electron microscopy techniques, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, positron annihilation spectroscopy, and density functional theory calculations unambiguously confirm the Fe-N-C species encapsulated on the NF support. Impressively, the achieved Fe-N-C/NF electrode, possessing a high number of active sites, high kinetics, and enhanced charge transport capability, displays outstanding electrocatalytic glucose oxidation activity. The low potential values of 1.31, 1.50, and 1.70 V vs. RHE are required to reach the current density of 10, 50, and 100 mA·cm-2, respectively, which are found to be significantly lower than those of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) counterpart (e.g., 1.57, 1.75, and 1.91 V vs. RHE), implying the outstanding GOR performance of the Fe-N-C/NF material and its potential in the energy-saving hydrogen production. Moreover, the obtained catalyst exhibits stability and a lower working cell voltage for GOR in comparison to OER counterparts, suggesting an impressive application of the electrode for energy-saving hydrogen production via GOR.
